Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Marine Biogeochemistry at the University of South Carolina
Award.AbstractNarration: The Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) program at the University of South Carolina located in Columbia, SC supports ten students each year during a ten week summer research experience. The research theme of this REU site is "Marine Biogeochemistry - from Salt Marshes to the Deep Ocean". Students have the opportunity to explore biogeochemical cycling in habitats that span the gradient from wetlands to coastal salt marshes to the deep-ocean, with the explicit consideration of human impacts and climate change on these systems. Within this framework, the program emphasizes the basics of the scientific method, hypothesis formulation, hypothesis testing, research ethics, and the fundamentals of written and oral science communication. Mentoring is provided by highly-qualified Marine Science Program and Department of Biological Sciences faculty whose research falls under the Marine Biogeochemistry umbrella. The program makes extensive use of USC's Baruch Institute for Marine and Coastal Sciences, located on the coast near Georgetown, SC. At the end of the summer, REU students present their results during a student research symposium and a research paper. Support provided by NSF includes funding for student stipends, student travel to and from the site, student housing and meals and some administrative costs.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Our REU site provided research experience for a total of 30 undergraduate students in the summers of 2013 to 2015. These students were involved in projects ranging from marine chemistry to benthic ecology under the guidance of 10 mentors. The students were trained in how to write a research proposal, general steps in the scientific method, science ethics and how to give a scientific presentation, both oral and poster formats. In 2016, REU student Allison Kline published the results of her summer research (with mentor Jay Pinckney) in the journal "Environmental Pollution".  One student each year was chosen to attend and present at a scientific meeting of their choice. In Year 1, Jessica Asirwantham went to the 2014 Ocean Sciences meeting in Honolulu, Hawaii. In Year 3,  Rachael Young attended the 2016 Ocean Sciences meeting in New Orleans, LA. (The student winner in Year 2 declined the award). All students gave a poster presentation at a research symposium to which the university public was invited. In Years 2 and 3, we teamed up with other REU programs on campus for a Summer Undergraduate Research Symposium which was very successful. Overall it was a great experience for both students and research mentors.
